quest_name: Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a

history.location_text:
Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a jump... higher! Even higher! One step forward. Squat down, stand up straight. One jump forward, one jump back - don't turn! Stand up, stop wincing and nursing your tail base... Not bad at all.

I think you are the one we need, Ranger. Our scholars invented a unique device, which was sent to the Institute of Inventions and Innovations on planet Bonnasis for patenting. Unfortunately, we didn't have time to test it thoroughly so now we can't complete the application for the patent. There is only one test remaining - field-testing - but it is the most important one. We have already rented a test lab in the Institute and invited stuntmen but they failed to complete the testing.

As a ranger, you must be perfectly trained. We will even pay you twice as much as a stuntman gets - it makes 65535 cr, if you go to planet Bonnasis (system Procyon) and manage to test the device. But keep in mind that the patent submission is due to expire, so you must do all the testing by 6 February 3000.
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
You took an aerocab that brought you to the Inventions and Innovations. It was near the Academy of Anthropological and Amorphous Anomalies. You entered and asked which way you should go.

A gloomy assistant accompanied you along the tortuous corridors. You met a Maloq with a stunt man's badge hopping with his crutches, then they carried by a litter with an unconscious man - your colleague. A gaal in a wheelchair saw where you were going. Then he approached you, gave you a sympathising look, and mentioned quietly: "Heh, he's so young", - after that he wheeled away.

The assistant brought you to the "Test laboratory No 13" and kindly opened the door.
- Ranger? - a fae stood up to meet you. - Nice to meet you, I'm professor Hab, I manage the testing of the device and collect all the information necessary for the patent application preparation. Have a sit.
You sat obediently on the offered chair.
- Stand up, now sit down again. Bounce on your toes. Higher. Still higher! Now hold your breath. Hold your left ear with your right hand and the right ear with your left hand... Not mine!!!
He measured your pulse and nodded with satisfaction.
- Excellent. Pulse, co-ordination, reflexes  - you are in perfect shape and this is very important for the "Jumper"'s testing. By the way, you may breathe.

You exhaled with relief:
choices: What exactly am I supposed to do?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- You must test the jumping backpack - "Jumper". We rented a pavilion for the testing and tossed a facility. Your task is to go through the labyrinth made of hanging platforms jumping from one platform to another using the "Jumper". The labyrinth consists of the starting and finishing points and five rows of platforms between them.  Your task is to make a number of jumps to get from the starting point through the labyrinth to the finishing point . And you can jump only within the row you are at or onto the platforms of the next row.

Jumps require power consumption, which is measured in ergo and depends on the length of the jump. You will have two batteries  20 ergo each. One battery is active, and the other is spare. Our technicians promise that would be enough.

There are additional devices somewhere on the platforms, which allow you to replace the active battery, top it up or even get back to the starting point where you can charge the both batteries and start the testing from the very beginning. If you want to cancel the testing and, accordingly, abandon your fee, you can use the emergency return button.
choices: Take me to the scaffold... I mean, to the testing facility. I agree to stretch my legs a little bit... Lord forbid, of course!
Please give me more details about the labyrinth's configuration and explain how I can go through it.
What is the power consumption during jumping?
You said something about additional devices in the labyrinth...
Please tell me once again -what is my task?
Can you tell me more about the "Jumper"? What's the hang of this device?
What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re at the very beginning and don’t yet know the critical parameters needed to plan a safe route: the exact layout (platform positions per row), the allowed jump rules in practice, and where the finish is relative to the start. Without the labyrinth’s configuration, any attempt to start immediately is blind and risks wasting ergo early, getting forced into expensive jumps, or missing useful devices (battery swap/charge/return) that might be positioned on specific platforms. The optimal first move is to request a full description/map-like explanation so we can plan an energy-efficient path and identify contingency options before committing.

ACTION: 2

The optimal first move is to request a full description/map-like explanation so we can plan an energy-efficient path and identify contingency options before committing.

history.location_text:
Instead of answering Hab pointed to the window opening to the testing pavilion. There were half a dozen of platforms about two meters in diameter each hanging behind the window at a height of almost 20 meters. The distance between them was from 2 to 10 meters. The platforms were white with one coloured stripe along the edge.

- There are five rows of platforms here, each row is marked with a certain colour. The technicians changed the configuration many times already making the facility easier and safer, so I have only general information about its structure: 
- Starting point
- Yellow row - 4 platforms
- Red row - 4 platforms
- Violet row - 5 platforms, plus one battery charger
- Blue row - 4 platforms, the teleport can be used here
- Green row - 3 platforms, the teleport is active here too
- Final point - the testing is over here.

I would advise you to drag your heels here and study the facility's structure first. When you reach the Green or Blue row, you will be able to return to the starting point, charge your batteries and do the testing from the beginning. But note - you can do it just once.
choices: Take me to the scaffold... I mean, to the testing facility. I agree to stretch my legs a little bit... Lord forbid, of course!
Please give me more details about the labyrinth's configuration and explain how I can go through it.
What is the power consumption during jumping?
You said something about additional devices in the labyrinth...
Please tell me once again -what is my task?
Can you tell me more about the "Jumper"? What's the hang of this device?
What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: Now we know the rows and the special devices: a charger in Violet, teleport return available in Blue/Green (usable only once to restart with full charge). The key remaining unknown for planning is whether our two 20-ergo batteries truly suffice for worst-case jumps and how ergo cost scales with jump distance (2–10 meters). Without the consumption rules, we can’t decide whether we should aim for the Violet charger early, conserve battery for reaching Blue/Green to use the one-time restart, or whether long jumps are prohibitively expensive. So the most strategically important next information is the power consumption per jump.

history.location_text:
Depending on the length of the jump, the power consumption will be the following:

2 meters - 4 ergo 
3-4 meters - 5 ergo
5 meters - 7 ergo
6-7 meters - 8 ergo
8 meters - 10 ergo
9-12 meters - 15 ergo

Our technicians promise that 40 ergo will be enough to go through the labyrinth. You are given two batteries  20 ergo each. Only one battery can be active - its power is used for the jump. But you can replace the battery with the help of the special device - there are such samples in the test labyrinth.

Before stepping onto the platforms, I need the operational details about these devices so we can plan around battery management (e.g., avoid getting stuck with an empty active battery and a full spare we can’t access).

history.location_text:
- In the first place, you can replace the active battery with the spare one  on every platform with an even number  and use it for jumping.
Secondly, there is a charger installed on the central platform of the Violet row  - it adds 12 ergo to the active battery automatically.
Thirdly, there is an accelerator on the first platform  of some row, I can't remember now which one. It will transfer you onto the first platform of the next sector just for 1 ergo. 
And of course, we will provide you with a portable teleport, which will help you to return to the starting point where you will be able to charge the both batteries and start from the beginning. But it's disposable and can be used only on the platforms of the Blue and Green rows!

What we still lack is the only thing that lets us plan an optimal (and safe) route: the actual configuration/numbering of platforms in each row and the distances between specific platforms (which determine ergo costs and whether we can reliably reach an even-numbered platform to swap, or the Violet center to recharge). Therefore the best next step is to request more detailed information on the labyrinth’s configuration and how to traverse it, before we commit to starting and risk landing on a dead-end with an empty active battery.

When we pressed for more configuration details, Hab repeated he only has general information—so there is no “map” to obtain here. Continuing to ask questions will just loop and delays the actual test. The rational move now is to begin the course and rely on in-course observation, aiming early for: (1) reaching even platforms when possible to preserve battery flexibility, (2) hitting Violet center for the +12 charge, and (3) keeping the one-time teleport as a contingency once we reach Blue/Green if energy looks tight.

history.location_text:
The professor wished you good luck and blessed you. Then he took you to the test pavilion.
- Note that the battery replacement devices are installed on the even platforms of each sector. Here is a portable teleport adjusted to return back here. You can use it only once - while passing the labyrinth' last two rows. The emergency return button means that you cancel the testing of just can't complete it. And in case of any accidents - well, you understand what I mean, mind your language and don't dirty the floor - our young ladies assisting in the lab have such a weak stomach.

You went up the stairs to the starting point. Meanwhile the professor and a dozen of his associates were making bets what platform you will fall from. 
"Snooks, lab rats", - you got furious and came to the edge. It is high! Round 20 meters, so the fall will be short but very painful. Well, you must jump. Which sector will you choose?
params: You are at the starting point
history.llm_response:
REASONING: First jump sets the tone for battery management. With 20 ergo in the active battery, an 8-meter jump would immediately burn 10 ergo (half the battery), while 5–6 meters costs 7–8 ergo and is safer for long-term endurance. Also, battery swapping is only possible on even-numbered platforms, so it’s strategically valuable to start on an even platform to keep flexibility from the very beginning (in case we need to switch batteries later without being forced into risky long jumps). Among the even Yellow platforms, Yellow-4 costs only 8 ergo versus Yellow-2 at 10 ergo. Therefore Yellow-4 gives both efficiency and early access to a swap device.

ACTION: 4
history.reasoning: First jump sets the tone for battery management. With 20 ergo in the active battery, an 8-meter jump would immediately burn 10 ergo (half the battery), while 5–6 meters costs 7–8 ergo and is safer for long-term endurance. Among the even Yellow platforms, Yellow-4 costs only 8 ergo versus Yellow-2 at 10 ergo. Therefore Yellow-4 gives both efficiency and early access to a swap device.

history.location_text:
You hit your heels on the platform nastily and groaned with pain. There was an inscription along the very edge of the platform scratched with some sharp thing:
"Ranger Bob was here. 1 January 3000"

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Yellow-4, which is an even-numbered platform, so we have access to a battery replacement device right now. The key constraint in this test is that we can only swap batteries on even platforms; if we later get forced onto odd platforms while the active battery is low, we could get trapped unable to switch to the spare even if it’s full.

Right now the active battery (№1) is down to 12 ergo. The forward progression jump is Red-4 at 5 meters (cost 7 ergo). If we jump now without swapping, we’d arrive at Red-4 with only 5 ergo active—still swappable there (even), but it leaves us much less margin if the next required jump is longer or if we end up needing to move through odd platforms.

Swapping now makes battery №2 (20 ergo) active and keeps battery №1 (12 ergo) as reserve. Then we can take the 5-meter jump to Red-4 while still having a healthy active charge afterward, which is the safest way to preserve flexibility and avoid getting stuck later.

ACTION: 1

history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’ve already used the even-platform swap device to put the full battery №2 (20 ergo) into active use, keeping battery №1 (12 ergo) as reserve. Swapping again right now would only downgrade our active charge back to 12 ergo, which reduces safety margin and provides no benefit.

We should advance to the next sector (Red row) while we have a strong active battery. The offered forward jump is to Red-4 at 5 meters, costing 7 ergo. That would leave battery №2 at 13 ergo on an even-numbered platform again (Red-4), preserving the ability to swap later if needed. The alternative (Yellow-3) is just lateral movement that doesn’t progress and likely wastes power unless it unlocks better routes—which we can’t see yet. No reason to hit emergency return.

history.location_text:
A soft fall with a roll and a roar of a parturient gobzaurus - you all but fell off the platform that turned out to be surprisingly slippery. You could hardly hold up and saw that the platform had a bad list.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Red-4 (even), so we have a swap device available, but swapping right now would make the weaker battery (№1 with 12 ergo) active and reduce our immediate safety margin for no clear gain. Our next strategic objective is the Violet row because its central platform has an automatic +12 ergo charger, which can effectively “refill” an active battery and extend our total range.

Between the two forward jumps, Violet-4 is much cheaper: 3 meters costs 5 ergo versus 6 meters costing 8 ergo. Taking Violet-4 also lands us on an even platform again (so we keep swap capability). Importantly, using battery №2 for this jump leaves it at 8 ergo (13 - 5), which is ideal because then the Violet charger’s +12 can potentially bring it back up to a full 20 when we reach the central Violet platform, maximizing benefit and minimizing wasted charge.

So the best move is to go to Violet-4 using the current active battery №2.

ACTION: 3

history.location_text:
The platform was flying at you. You tried to remember some prayers but only nasty stories and recipes of the Maloq cuisine came to your mind. You were lucky though and escaped just with fright and injured manhood - fortunately, no self-maiming.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Violet-4 (even), so we have a battery replacement device available. The key objective in the Violet row is the central platform (Violet-3), because it has the automatic charger (+12 ergo to the *active* battery). Getting that charge in the most advantageous way is crucial for finishing the whole course.

From Violet-4 we can jump to Violet-3, but it’s a 6-meter jump (costs 8 ergo). If we keep battery №2 active (currently 8 ergo), that jump would drain it to 0 and then the charger would only bring it up to 12—leaving us on an odd platform (no swap device) with a relatively low active charge, which is risky for the next sector transitions.

If we swap now, battery №1 (12 ergo) becomes active. Then the 6-meter jump to Violet-3 costs 8 ergo, leaving 4 ergo, and the charger will boost it to 16. That’s a much safer active reserve to continue onward from an odd platform where we can’t swap immediately.

So: swap batteries now to maximize the benefit of the Violet charger and keep a safer energy buffer.

ACTION: 1

The central platform of the Violet row is Violet-3, and it automatically adds +12 ergo to the *active* battery. Reaching it as soon as possible is the best strategic move because it increases our total available energy for the remaining sectors (Blue and Green) where we may need the one-time teleport as an emergency fallback.

Jumping from Violet-4 to Violet-3 is 6 meters, costing 8 ergo. With battery №1 active at 12, we can afford it and will arrive with 4 ergo active, then immediately get +12 from the charger, bringing the active battery up to 16 ergo—much safer for the next stage. Going to Violet-5 instead doesn’t get the charge and risks landing on an odd platform with no swap access.

history.location_text:
Hardly had you landed onto the platform, an automated voice said:
"Active battery, current charge - 4 ergo. Boost charging function is active. Boost charging complete. Active battery, current charge - 16 ergo"

"Heh, I wish my spaceship had such a battery", - you thought enviously.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re leaving Violet after successfully using the central charger, so our immediate goal is to enter the Blue row with as much charge as possible, because we still must cross Blue → Green → Final, and battery swaps are only possible on even-numbered platforms.

From Violet-3:
- To Blue-2 is 5 m (7 ergo), landing on an even platform (swap possible) but costs a lot.
- To Blue-3 is 2 m (4 ergo), cheapest by far, but lands on an odd platform (no swap device).
- To Blue-4 is 5 m (7 ergo), same cost as Blue-2, even platform.

Right now our active battery is strong (16 ergo), and the spare is weak (8 ergo). Saving ergo now is valuable, and we’re not in immediate danger of needing a battery swap on the very next step because 12 ergo remaining after the 2-meter jump is still a workable buffer for several medium jumps. Also, once in the Blue row, we can use the disposable teleport if things go badly—but we should conserve that as a last-resort option.

So the best move is the cheapest entry into Blue: Blue-3 for 4 ergo.

history.location_text:
After landing onto the very edge of the platform, you saw a scratched inscription:
"Bob was h..." - after "h" it was chopped and a long deep scar along with five minor ones stretched to the edge of the platform.

The portable teleport started peeping on your belt. That meant it was active. It will help you to return to the starting point to charge the batteries and  - good luck again!
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Blue-3 (odd), so right now we **cannot** swap batteries if the active one runs low. Active battery №1 has 12 ergo; spare №2 has 8 ergo, but it’s effectively “locked” until we reach an **even-numbered platform**.

Using the teleport now would reset everything and restore both batteries to 20, but it’s disposable and best saved for a true emergency (e.g., we miscalculate and end up with an impossible jump sequence). We’re already deep into the course and still have enough charge to maneuver into a safer position.

From here:
- Jumping directly to **Green-2 (8 m)** costs **10 ergo**, leaving us with only **2 ergo active**—dangerous even though Green-2 is even.
- Jumping directly to **Green-3 (4 m)** costs **5 ergo**, leaving **7 ergo**, but we’d land on **odd** again and still be unable to swap.
- Jumping to **Blue-4 (4 m)** costs **5 ergo**, leaving **7 ergo**, and crucially puts us on **even** (so we can swap and regain flexibility before committing to the Green row).

So the best tactical move is to go to **Blue-4** to unlock battery swapping before pushing onward.

history.location_text:
"Ouch!"
The landing was abysmal this time - your feet were burning like on fire, and your completely new space-boots with magnetic soles squished softly and decided to go their own way, bit by bit - the sole of the right boot flew off to the right with a subtle whizz.

The portable teleport started beeping on your belt. That meant it was active. It will help you to return to the starting point to charge the batteries and  - good luck again!
There is a battery replacement device here too.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Blue-4 (even), so we can swap batteries here, and the teleport is also available. Current energy is the real problem: active battery №1 has 7 ergo, spare №2 has 8.

Possible moves:
- To Green-3 is 3 meters → costs 5 ergo.  
  • If we go without swapping: 7 → 2 ergo left on Green-3 (odd), and with 2 ergo we can’t make any further jump (minimum cost is 4).  
  • If we swap first: 8 → 3 ergo left on Green-3, still can’t make the next jump.  
So going to Green-3 now is almost certainly a dead end.

- To Blue-3 is 4 meters → costs 5 ergo.  
  • Without swapping: 7 → 2 ergo on Blue-3 (odd), stuck.  
  • With swapping: 8 → 3 ergo on Blue-3, stuck.

So neither swapping nor moving helps: we don’t have enough charge to both move and still be able to make a subsequent jump. That means continuing without reset will likely force an emergency failure button later.

Teleport is disposable but this is exactly the scenario it’s meant for: we reached Blue (where it’s allowed), discovered we’re energy-starved, and need a full restart to complete the test successfully. Therefore we should use the teleport now to return, fully recharge both batteries, and rerun the route more efficiently.

history.location_text:
You transferred to the starting point. The professor ran to you and hooked up the charger to the batteries:
- So, did you manage to study the labyrinth well enough? Note, you have no more chances to return. And we are pressed for time - we need to format the report, attach it to the application form, register and queue to the acceptance committee. Hurry up, please. You are not the only one after 65535 credits. Honestly, I don't cherish high hopes that you will be a success. The technicians must have done something wrong again reconfiguring the facility. Though they swear that the labyrinth is passable...

You reassured the scholar that you would manage it by all means and got ready for the first jump...
params: You are at the starting point
history.llm_response:

That means we should minimize early expenditure and keep access to battery-swap devices (only on even-numbered platforms) to avoid getting trapped with an empty active battery.

From the start, the cheapest jump is to Yellow-3 (7 ergo), but it’s an odd platform (no swap). Yellow-4 costs only 8 ergo (still efficient) and is even, immediately giving us a swap point and flexibility. Yellow-1/Yellow-2 both cost 10 ergo (too expensive up front).

So the best controlled, energy-efficient and flexible opening is to land on Yellow-4.

history.location_text:
" Ranger Bob was here 1 January 3000", - you saw that inscription for the second time already and these simple words awoke your creativity. Soon a new inscription spread along the platform:
"And ranger Ranger was here twice. 1 January 3000!"

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:

Last attempt failed because we reached Blue-4 with too little charge left to make a further jump and still have enough energy to continue (the minimum jump cost is 4 ergo, and we were dropping to 2–3 ergo after the next move).

Right now we’re on Yellow-4 (even), so we *can* swap—but swapping here would spend our fresh 20-ergo battery too early, and we’ll need that larger reserve later for the Violet center charger trick. The key is to arrive at Violet-3 with a reasonably charged *active* battery so that after the jump (cost 8) the charger’s +12 lifts us to a high value (ideally close to 20), giving us enough to go Blue → Green without using extra “detour” jumps.

So we keep battery №1 active for this sector transition, make the 5-meter jump to Red-4 (7 ergo), and then we can swap on Red-4 (even) if needed—preserving the 20-ergo battery for the Violet row where it pays off most.

The platform was flying at you. You tried to remember some prayers but only nasty stories and recipes of the Maloq cuisine came to your mind. You were lucky though and escaped just with fright and injured manhood - fortunately, no self-maiming.

There is a battery replacement device here.

"Ranger have been here. I have also been there, and there. And I'm going to jump there.... On the whole, I've been here twice!"

- Blue-3 → Green-2 is 8 m = 10 ergo, leaving only 5 ergo active. That’s risky because the final jump from Green to Finish could easily cost 7–10 ergo, and we’d likely fail.
- Blue-3 → Blue-4 is 4 m = 5 ergo, but it doesn’t advance sectors and costs energy; we’d then still need another jump into Green. Since the spare battery is weak, reaching an even platform for swapping isn’t valuable.

So we should go straight to Green-3.

It would have been more logical to make it red - most of the accidents happen here. On the other side, if most of the testers were Pelengs with green blood, this colour is matching.

history.location_text:
Your last jump was unbelievably beautiful - a storm of applause came from underneath and in the last moment you realised that the crowd of on-lookers will soon turn into the crowd of victims because you were landing right on their heads. Fortunately, everything turned out well and nobody was hurt.

- At last! - the professor was shaking your hand in excitement. - We thought we would have to cancel the project due to excess life and health risk. The rectorate started to look awry at us when we receive the bills for the medicine. You deserved your award, Ranger, all you need to do now is to get back to your employer on the Bonnasis planet to take it. By the way, I want to thank you personally.
- What for?
- Don't you understand? I staked half of my yearly salary on you if you go through the labyrinth! By the way, do you want to pocket a little bit more?
params: You are at the finishing point
choices: So what I am supposed to do? To jump while you're staking on me?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- Not at all. It's just additional money. You will get your 65535 credits for sure but you can also earn a little bit more...
- How far is this "more" and what do I need to do?
- See, I'm sure the commission will want to watch the device operating. After you found the best route, any assistant can manage it. Furthermore, your fee is so...formidable that we can't hire you to go through the labyrinth again. But there is one problem - the batteries are spent. I'd like to request you to use one of the first configurations of the testing facility to charge the batteries to the maximum , and I'll pay you 1000 cr. But at first you'll have to jump with the "Jumper" a little bit. You lose nothing and can get some profit - what would you say?
choices: Bad idea, I have already hit my jumping target for the next year. Good bye!

Since the teleport is already spent and accidents here are described as common and painful, taking an optional extra run with near-dead batteries is an unnecessary risk that could turn a completed success into a failure. The rational play is to lock in the guaranteed reward and walk away.
